OCTEON PCI driver directory structure

/usr/local/Cavium_Networks/OCTEON-SDK (default OCTEON OCTEON SDK Location)
 | 
 |--components
    |
    |--driver  ($DRIVER_ROOT)
        |
        |--Makefile (Top-level Makefile to compile the host components)
        |
        |--README.txt (Compilation instructions)
        |
        |--core   (Source files for the PCI driver component running on OCTEON cores)
        |
        |--common (Structures & macros shared by the host and core components)
        |
        |--bin    (All host executable files and core applications are linked from
        |          this directory)
        |
        |--host
            |
            |--include  (Header files used by host component files)
            |
            |--driver
            |   |
            |   |--linux (Linux specific Host module sources & Makefile)
            |   |
            |   |--osi   (OS-independent driver implementation)
            |
            |--api    (User level API for interacting with driver)
            |
            |--utils  (Source code for user-space utilities )
            |
            |--test  (Source code for user-space test programs)
               |
               |--kernel
                   |
                   |-- req_resp (Linux kernel-space test program to demonstrate
                   |             request/response when OCTEON is a co-processor)
                   |
                   |-- droq_test (Linux kernel-space test program to demonstrate
                                  packet transfer on OCTEON output queues)

NOTE: The above diagram assumes that the OCTEON-SDK and OCTEON-PCI-BASE packages were installed at their default locations.

All host components can be built using the Makefile at $DRIVER_ROOT. The core component is included as a library when compiling the core application. See the README.txt file at $DRIVER_ROOT for more compilation instructions.




IMPORTANT

Only the components of the driver enabled in the Makefile at OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/host/driver/linux is supported. Other components may be removed in the future and their usability is not guaranteed.
